He made nearly 30 films, the latter ones being especially notable: La Ronde (1950), Le Plaisir (1952), The Earrings of Madame de… (1953) and Lola Montès (1955). He was credited as Max Opuls on several of his American films, including The Reckle

heading: Deaths
txt: Tom Brown, American trombonist (b. 1888)

entities.title: Tom Brown (trombonist)
entities.description: Tom Brown, sometimes known by the nickname Red Brown, was an early New Orleans dixieland jazz trombonist. He also played string bass professionally.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Benjamin Howard, Canadian businessman and politician (b. 1885)

entities.title: Charles Benjamin Howard
entities.description: Charles Benjamin Howard was a Liberal party member of the House of Commons of Canada. He was born in Smith's Mills, Quebec in Stanstead County and became a businessman, industrialist and lumber merchant.

heading: Deaths
txt: Viola Liuzzo, American civil rights activist (b. 1925)

entities.description: Viola Fauver Liuzzo was an American housewife and civil rights activist. entities.title: Goodman Ace
entities.description: Goodman Ace, born Goodman Aiskowitz, was an American humorist, radio writer and comedian, television writer, and magazine columnist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bob Waterfield, American football player and coach (b. 1920)

entities.title: Bob Waterfield
entities.description: Robert Stanton Waterfield was an American football player and coach and motion picture actor and producer. He played quarterback for the UCLA Bruins and Cleveland/Los Angeles Rams and was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1965. His No. 7 jersey was retired by the Los Angeles Rams in 1952.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Joffrey, American dancer, choreographer, and director, co-founded the Joffrey Ballet (b. 1930)

entities.title: Robert Joffrey
entities.description: Robert Joffrey was an American dancer, teacher, producer, choreographer, and co-founder of the Joffrey Ballet, known for his highly imaginative modern ballets. He was born Anver Bey Abdullah Jaffa Khan in Seattle, Washington to a Pashtun father from Afghanistan and a mother from Italy.

entities.title: Joffrey Ballet
entities.description: The Joffrey Ballet, based in Chicago, Illinois, is a premier dance company. The Joffrey regularly performs both classical ballets, including Romeo & Juliet and The Nutcracker, and modern dance pieces. They are also noted for their 1987 performances of Stravinsky's The Rite of Spring, where they reconstructed the orgiinal choreography—which was long thought to be lost—from the 1913 premiere. heading: Deaths
txt: Marcel Lefebvre, French-Swiss archbishop (b. 1905)

entities.title: Marcel Lefebvre
entities.description: Marcel François Marie Joseph Lefebvre was a French Roman Catholic archbishop. In 1970, he founded the Society of Saint Pius X (SSPX) as a small community of seminarians in the village of Écône, Switzerland, with the permission of Bishop François Charrière of Fribourg. In 1975, after a flare of tensions with the Holy See, Lefebvre was ordered to disband the society, but ignored the decision. In 198

heading: Deaths
txt: Nancy Walker, American actress, singer, and director (b. 1922)

entities.title: Nancy Walker
entities.description: Nancy Walker was an American actress and comedian of stage, screen, and television. She was also a film and television director. heading: Deaths
txt: Angelines Fernández, Spanish-Mexican actress (b. 1922)

entities.title: Angelines Fernández
entities.description: María de los Ángeles "Angelines" Fernández Abad was a Spanish-born Mexican actress of film and television. She is best remembered for playing Doña Clotilde "La Bruja del 71" in the sitcom El Chavo del Ocho. She was an anti-Franco refugee who remained in Mexico from 1947 until the end of her life.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cal Ripken, Sr., American baseball player, coach, and manager (b. 1936)

entities.title: Cal Ripken, Sr.
entities.description: Calvin Edwin Ripken Sr. was a coach and manager in Major League Baseball who spent 36 years in the Baltimore Orioles organization, also as a player and scout. He played in the Orioles' farm system beginning in 1957, and later served as manager of the parent club, on which his sons Cal Jr. and Billy played.

heading: Deaths
txt: Helen Martin, American actress (b. 1909)

entities.title: Helen Martin
entities.description: Helen Dorothy Martin was an American actress of stage and television. Martin's career spanned over 60 years, appearing first on stage and later in film and television. Martin is best known for her roles as Wanda on the CBS sitcom Good Times (1974–1979) and as Pearl Shay on the NBC sitcom 227 (1985–1990).

heading: Deaths
txt: Brian Trubshaw, English cricketer and pilot (b. 1924)

entities.title: Brian Trubshaw
entities.description: Ernest Brian Trubshaw, CBE, MVO was a leading test pilot, and the first British pilot to fly Concorde, in April 1969.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kenneth Wolstenholme, English journalist and sportscaster (b. 1920)

entities.title: Kenneth Wolstenholme
entities.description: Kenneth Wolstenholme, DFC & Bar was an English football commentator for BBC television in the 1950s and 1960s. In the final moments of the 1966 FIFA World Cup, he said "some people are on the pitch...they think it's all over....it is now!" as Geoff Hurst scored England's fourth goal. The phrase has become part of British popular culture.

entities.description: Paul William Henning was an American producer and screenwriter. Most famous for the television sitcom The Beverly Hillbillies, he was also crucial in developing the "rural" comedies Petticoat Junction (1963–1970) and Green Acres (1965–1971) for CBS. entities.description: Andranik Nahapeti Margaryan served as the Prime Minister of Armenia from 12 May 2000, when the President appointed him, until his death on 25 March 2007. heading: Deaths
txt: Ben Carnevale, American basketball player and coach (b. 1915)

entities.title: Ben Carnevale
entities.description: Bernard Louis Carnevale was an American basketball coach and college athletic administrator. He served as the head basketball coach at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill from 1944 to 1946 and the United States Naval Academy from 1946 to 1966, compiling a career college basketball coaching record of 309–171. Carnevale was the athletic director at the College of William & Mary from 1972

entities.title: McMuffin
entities.description: McMuffin is a family of breakfast sandwiches sold by the international fast food restaurant chain McDonald's. The Egg McMuffin is the signature sandwich, which was invented in 1972 by Herb Peterson to resemble eggs Benedict, a traditional American breakfast dish with English muffins, ham, eggs and hollandaise sauce.

entities.title: Crosfield Electronics
entities.description: Crosfield Electronics was a British electronics imaging company founded by John Crosfield and Dennis Bent in 1947 to produce process imaging devices for the print industry. The firm was notable for its innovation in colour drum scanning in its Scanatron (1959) and later Magnascan (1969) products.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edd Gould, English animator and voice actor, founded Eddsworld (b. 1988)

entities.title: Eddsworld
entities.description: Eddsworld is a British animated comedy web series of flash animations, comics, and browser games created by Edd Gould. They are distributed on Newgrounds, DeviantArt, YouTube, Albino Blacksheep, Tumblr, and BBC. They were previously distributed on SheezyArt and the main Eddsworld site until they were shut down.

entities.description: George Richard Fischbeck,, better known as Dr. George Fischbeck, was an American television weatherman on KOB-TV in Albuquerque, New Mexico from the early 1960s to early 1970s. In 1972 he moved to KABC-TV in Los Angeles, replacing Alan Sloane, where he became a staple on the station's Eyewitness News broadcasts. heading: Deaths
txt: Shannon Bolin, American actress and singer (b. 1917)

entities.title: Shannon Bolin
entities.description: Ione Shannon Bolin was an American actress and singer. A March 10, 1941, article in The Mason City Globe-Gazette said that she was "known as 'The Lady with the Dark Blue Voice.'"

heading: Deaths
txt: Cuthbert Sebastian, St. Kitts and Nevis politician (b. 1921)

entities.title: Cuthbert Sebastian
entities.description: Sir Cuthbert Montraville Sebastian was the Governor-General of St. Kitts and Nevis from 1996 to 2013. He was appointed Governor-General in 1995 and was sworn in on 1 January 1996. While in office, he was the world's oldest serving de facto head of state. His retirement was announced on 25 December 2012 and became effective on 1 January 2013.

heading: Deaths
txt: Zell Miller,  American author and politician (b. 1932)

entities.title: Zell Miller
entities.description: Zell Bryan Miller was an American author and politician from the state of Georgia. A Democrat, Miller served as lieutenant governor from 1975 to 1991, 79th Governor of Georgia from 1991 to 1999, and as U.S. Senator from 2000 to 2005.

heading: Deaths
txt: Scott Walker, American-born British singer-songwriter (b. 1943)

entities.title: Scott Walker (singer)
entities.description: Noel Scott Engel better known by the stage name Scott Walker, was an American singer-songwriter, composer and record producer who resided in England. Walker was known for his baritone voice and an unorthodox career path which took him from 1960s teen pop icon to 21st-century avant-garde musician. heading: Deaths
txt: Floyd Cardoz, Indian-born American chef (b. 1960)

entities.title: Floyd Cardoz
entities.description: Floyd Cardoz was an Indian-born American chef. He was born in Mumbai. He owned the New York City eatery Paowalla and was executive chef at Tabla, as well as victor on Top Chef Masters Season 3 in 2011. His New York restaurants were known for food melding Indian flavours and spices with western cuisine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Beverly Cleary, American author (b. 1916)

entities.title: Beverly Cleary
entities.description: Beverly Atlee Cleary was an American writer of children's and young adult fiction. One of America's most successful authors, 91 million copies of her books have been sold worldwide since her first book was published in 1950. Some of her best known characters are Ramona Quimby and Beezus Quimby, Henry Huggins and his dog Ribsy, and Ralph S. Mouse.
